newsitem.title: ESTONIA: ESTONIA-FINMIN SAYS RULES NEEDED BEFORE CREDIT RATING.
newsitem.headline: ESTONIA-FINMIN SAYS RULES NEEDED BEFORE CREDIT RATING.

text.p: Estonia's Finance Minister Mart Opmann said on Thursday that Estonia would be ready for a country credit rating after controls on local government foreign borrowing were in place.
"We have to regulate the external loans taken by local governments," Opmann told Reuters in an interview.
"First of all they should be approved in the Ministry of Finance so that loans taken by state instutitions can be regulated by the state.
"After that I do not see any opposition to this idea (of a country credit rating)."

However Opmann said the decision lay with the central bank that has ongoing talks with the country's commercial banks over a credit rating for Estonia, the only Baltic country that has not yet sought an international rating.
"Just now the question depends on the decision on the Bank of Estonia -- yes or not, and when," he said.
However Opmann said he was aware that imposing controls on local govrnment borrowing was not easy and declined to speculate on any timeframe.
"The draft law (on regulating local government borrowing) has been submitted to parliment, but has not passed the first reading," he said.
"This is a question of economic policy. According to the Estonian constitution local governments are quite independent and now the state is trying to regulate them, so it is a very hard question."
